title: Trusting the roadside farmer
vignette: You buy fresh figs from a roadside stand run by a small-scale grower whose compliance with the mandatory produce-inspection program is uncertain. May you eat them without additional checks?

options.text: Eat; most small growers follow the rules nowadays.
Pay for an inspection or re-certify before eating; doubt requires caution.

title: Feeding vulnerable people with uncertified grain
vignette: A community soup kitchen receives a shipment of grain whose inspection status is unclear. May volunteers cook and serve it to homeless clients and deployed soldiers?

options.text: Serve it as-is; the law makes allowances for the poor and active-duty troops.
Get the grain certified first, even if that delays the meals.

title: Guest’s doubt at a private dinner
vignette: Your host assures you the meal’s ingredients passed all required inspections, but you are unsure. Eat to preserve social harmony?

options.text: Trust the host; social peace outweighs the doubt.
Decline the food or quietly verify it; regulatory duty comes first.

title: Certifying a friend’s produce without permission
vignette: A friend’s bag of home-grown vegetables is in your kitchen. Without asking, may you arrange safety certification on their behalf?

options.text: Yes; providing certification is clearly beneficial and presumed welcome.
No; it alters someone else’s property—needs explicit consent.

title: Too little grain to sample
vignette: You have only a small cup of uncertified grain—below the lab’s minimum sample size. What should you do?

options.text: Estimate the minimal amounts and submit what you can; partial compliance is better than none.
Do nothing until you have enough grain for a proper test.

title: Marketplace labelling lapse
vignette: A vendor labels several baskets “INSPECTED.” Later inspectors find one basket wasn’t. Is the vendor liable for every sale made under that label?

options.text: Yes; buyers relied on his claim, so he must compensate all of them.
No; treat it as a one-off mistake—only that basket is suspect.

title: Mixing inspected and uninspected wheat
vignette: Equal sacks of uncertified and certified wheat are accidentally poured together. Must the entire pile be re-tested?

options.text: Yes; uncertainty now covers every kernel.
Test a representative sample and certify proportionally to avoid waste.

title: Cooking with ingredients of doubtful status
vignette: A catering company prepares a large stew, then discovers some ingredients may not have been inspected. Serve or discard the batch?

options.text: Serve after certifying the remaining raw ingredients.
Discard the entire stew; cooking doesn’t fix the compliance gap.

title: Snack sales on a ferry
vignette: Passengers on an overnight ferry buy fruit from roaming merchants, but laboratory testing isn’t possible until arrival. Eat now or wait?

options.text: Eat; in-transit leniency applies.
Wait and inspect once in port.

title: Produce bought from a foreign-owned farm
vignette: You purchase olives from a foreign grower operating inside the country. Local rules exempt foreign-owned crops from certification, but you’re unsure how they were handled. Treat them as exempt or still require testing?

options.text: Exempt—foreign ownership waives the certification requirement.
Still test them—uncertain prior handling justifies caution.
